Topic.Title: What I said in the post it won`t take

Message.Msg: I was at the computer at 8:30am Swiss time. That is 2:30 am ET in the US. It is now 12:30 pm Swiss time. If you take the time to look you will see all my post, including those under aaplboost take place between roughly 8am and 10pm Swiss time--that is between 2am and 4pm ET in the US. Does your zevoter speak German? Für das, hast du keine Antwort (You don`t have an answer for that. Literally--For that, have you no answer). Like your other friend, you are making a fool of yourself. I have nothing against BAC. I am also not attached to my TA forecasts or the need to be right. If the tape proves me otherwise, I change my tune and get out of the trade. You are like a birther, even if I could give you undeniable truth about my identity you wouldn`t believe it... and it is doubtful that you would ever have the integrity to admit your errant presumptuousness and say something like, "Sorry, my bad. I was being a fool." You are worse than the people you seem to enjoy ridiculing because of your smug certainty in the face of evidence that should convince you otherwise. If you truly had an acute sense of discernment (or any real sense of subtlety and differentiation) you would recognize that I am not who you think I am. And if you had any character, you would admit your juvenile knee-jerk misinterpretations and discard your need to so quickly indulge in Schadenfreude. But, so is cyber space.

Message.Title: Q: What's the difference between a BAC financial officer and a used car salesman?
Message.Msg: A: The car salesman probably knows what he's lying about. There's a lengthy article in The current issue of the Atlantic Magazine titled "What's Inside America's Banks?" The short answer is "No one knows, including the banks." The head of investor relations at GS, Dane Holmes, is quoted as saying "People don't understand the big banks" because "there is a lack of transparency". (He later clarified that he was talking about average people, not the sophisticated institutional investors he interacts with.) However, even more disconcerting is that many of those 'people 'in the know' don't seem to understand or trust the banks either. A survey by Barclays Capital found that more than half of the institutional investors interviewed did not trust how the banks measured and reported the riskiness of their assets. When hedge fund managers were asked how trustworthy they find "risk weightings" - the numbers banks use to calculate how much cash cushion they should set aside to cover potential losses - about 60% of those managers answered '1 or 2' on a 5-point scale, with '1' indicating 'not trustworthy at all'. NONE of them gave the banks a '5'. I'm impressed by the number of trusting souls here who are apparently convinced that they're smarter than the average hedge fund manager! Still, if you want to shovel into a 'black box' investment vehicle, why choose BAC? ROTFLMAO the Vegas casinos offer comparable 'investment opportunities', complete with flashing lights and music, and even publish the payout rates so you know how much you should expect to lose before you start playing their slots. DISCLAIMER: In January of 2000, The Atlantic also published parts of Glassman and Hassett's notorious and thoroughly discredited work, "DOW 36,000: The New Strategy For Profiting From The Coming Rise in the Stock Market", which predicted that with a few years of its publication (1999) the DOW would be at 36,000 or more. ROTFLMAO maybe you can all start side-betting among yourselves as to when that number will be reached.

Message.Title: BAC has been strongly capital-generative
Message.Msg: Bank of America (BAC) has been strongly capital-generative since Mr. Brian Moynihan became CEO in December 2009. For example, company reports show the Tier 1 capital ratio, calculated in accordance with today's regulatory regime, increased to 11.4%, presently from 7.8% at the end of 2009. In 2012, the capital-build reduced investor concerns, prevalent in August 2011 when Mr. Warren Buffet invested $5 billion in preferred shares, that the bank did not have enough capital and would need to issue common stock at distressed prices. We believe the lower risk of "dilution" by additional share issuance at low prices accounted for the strong performance of the stock. Expect Stock Buyback in 2013 In 2013, BAC appears to have sufficient capital and, is better capitalized than J.P. Morgan Chase (JPM) and Citigroup (C) under the Basel 3 capital regime that is now an important focus of regulators. This means capital generated in the year will potentially and partly be available for return to stockholders, and we expect the announcement of a stock buyback possibly as early as March 2013

Topic.Title: BAC has been strongly capital-generative

Topic.Title: Credit Suisse sell side analyst looking like a real jerk today...

Message.Msg: The analyst stated BAC forward p/e was 12.6 compared to 9.7 for other banks. Therefore he implied it was over priced. The reason BAC has a higher p/e is due to the fact it has the largest comeback from housing costs and as those costs quickly go away it will dramatically increase profits. This analyst should have known this, my guess it was a planned shakeout of small investors to give others a quick profit. All is my opinion-

Topic.Title: Credit Suisse downgrades BAC to neutral but increases price target to $12?

Message.Msg: "Best clients?" Even if one were to believe your "manipulated market" theory (which I'll confess I don't), the fact remains that as the price dropped yesterday the buying opportunity presented itself for all of us--even a puny individual investor like me. I added to my position at $11.90, and then I added to my position again at $11.50. I was delighted to have had the opportunity to buy more under $12. When the share price drops, for whatever reason, we all have the opportunity to take advantage of the dip--or not. And that's true whether we're best clients, marginal clients, or non-clients.
